title: New home sales bounce back to mid-2018 levels
text:
Sales of new homes have rebounded by 5.7 per cent in September, rising to levels not seen since the second half of 2018 and suggesting an upturn in building approvals will follow shortly, according to new Housing Industry Association figures.

This is the second consecutive monthly increase in new home sales, indicating that confidence has returned, HIA economist Angela Lillicrap said.

New home sales bounced back in September, suggesting a recovery in building approvals is imminent. Mark Merton

The HIA New Home Sales report shows new home sales rose for the month in all the states except for NSW which recorded a 12.1 per cent decline.

Sales of new homes surged by 11 per cent in Victoria as strong population growth and low unemployment continued to support demand for new homes in the state.

Queensland notched up a 1.7 per cent increase in sales, South Australia lifted 18 per cent and Western Australia was up 13.6 per cent.
description: Second monthly rebound in a row suggests an upturn in building approvals will follow shortly, according to the HIA.
